history.content: No, an A+ really doesn't matter, though a good grade in the subject you wish to study is useful.  The most important thing is getting some research experience for your PhD application, since ultimately that's what a PhD student is hired to do.  3 majors is not worth it (at most double), since the opportunity cost is time spent researching.

children.subject: One thing to note is that Stanford/MIT may not have the best PhD department in the area that you wish to pursue. Try to keep this in mind instead of blindly applying to schools because they are "top" in some arbitrary ranking.
As a follow up, how would you know which school is good at a particular field?

I mean if you can get an A+ with essentially the same effort it would take for you to get an A then go for it, but unless you have a whole transcript of A+s you won't stand out much compared to someone with straight As. Even if you do, academic excellence is not the sole focus of a PhD program (and not even the primary focus, frankly), and research and LORs are both crucial. Triple majoring is not going to be a game changer for PhD committees and I advise against pursuing it if that's the goal you have in mind; instead you should only pursue it if you have an active interest in all three fields and can make time for the course load while still exploring extra curricular avenues. Anon Scale also makes an excellent point about not being enamoured by just the brand name when the school might not be renowned for the research field you're interested in
I think it is recommended to keep it above a 3.7 or at least a 3.5-3.3. But other than that, loc and research matters way more.

One followup question, if I have average grades but adequate research experiences, do I have still have a shot applying for the top CS programs?  Does GPA not really matter that much as long as it's above 3.0?

Matters for certain professors at Berkeley (check this post out @9629). However it's not really a good metric for PhD admissions (LOR + research weigh much more as others have said).

Also I'm not sure what your background is but if you are interested in getting a PhD try to get research as soon as possible. That will 1) give you actual experience so you can actually decide if it's what you want to do and 2) orient you towards a specific field/topic so you can narrow down what you want to do. ML/Data Science/Stats is pretty hype right now, but be sure that that's what you actually want to do. Also a personal rec is to take more math classes, since topics from classes like Math 110 and Math 104 show up everywhere.

Sorry I was bored looking at the piazza and I just came across this but - do you actually want to do a PhD? I'm a junior who is most likely heading towards a PhD and most people who I knew freshman year who were into the idea of a PhD have realized by now that it isn't for them (not that no one sticks with it). What you should realize is that you should do a PhD if you find an area that you genuinely have a lot of interest and excitement in AND you enjoy doing research. Considering you have taken very little CS so far, you probably don't know which area you will love, or even if there will be such an area. Think of it this way - if you want to get a PhD in an area, you should be so excited about it that you are willing to take a significant pay cut for anywhere from 5-10 years to just focus on that area (keep in mind that applying to PhD is done by area of study/professor so Stanford sounds fancy but they may not have a professor interested in what you want to do or they might have a professor but they are not looking for students that year). It's a big commitment and it's not worth it for the vast majority of people. I recommend trying to get research as early as next semester, just to dip your toes in (don't get your mind set on any specific lab already - as a freshman you may have to email a lot of grad students to get something). Anyway, if you still are sure you want to do a PhD I cannot recommend enough dropping to one major, maybe two. I'm a double major, but double majoring in CS and math is brutal and will honestly probably hurt you more than it will help. Keeping a high GPA will be very difficult and both majors will take up a lot of your time which would be better spent doing research. And it's not that impressive to colleges, they don't really care about how well you take tests because a PhD program is not college pt.2 it's basically a job.
